name: V-022: Gully Cleansing and Tanker Operations

competencies.name: Operative confirms they have been trained to operate gully cleansing and tanker equipment
competencies.supportingText:
Operative reports any damaged or defective items to supervisor and requests replacements
  1. What is the company procedure for reporting damaged and defective working equipment to your supervisor?

competencies.name: Operative uses equipment issued by the company and does not use unauthorised tools
competencies.supportingText:
Operative reports to supervisor if any equipment becomes damaged during the working day and puts it aside
  1. What is the company procedure for reporting damage to tools to your supervisor?

competencies.name: Operative checks ancillary work equipment is in working order before starting work
Operative reports any damaged or defective items to supervisor and requests replacements
Operative reports to supervisor if any equipment becomes damaged during the working day and puts it aside
Operative  wears the correct personal protection equipment supplied by the company at all times
Operative follows company procedure regarding the cleaning  of equipment and disposal
Operative follows company procedure regarding the disposal of waste liquids
competencies.supportingText:
Driver reports defective tankers and does not attempt to use them
  1. What is the company procedure for reporting defective tankers to your supervisor?

competencies.name: Operative always cleans hands before eating, drinking, smoking or going to the toilet
Driver carries out detailed daily checks of the vehicle and the associated equipment including pressure relief valves, hoses, and vacuum and pressure gauges
Driver reports defective tankers and does not attempt to use them
Driver does not exceed safe working pressures when working with pressure vacuum tankers
Driver remains close to a vehicle with a running engine when operating equipment
Operative applies the brake, switches off the engine and locks the doors when vehicle is  unattended
Operative avoids contact with moving or rotating parts
Operative operates equipment from ground level
Operative uses the grab handles and steps provided when mounting the vehicle
competencies.supportingText:
Operative only carries out any maintenance or repairs that they have been trained to perform
  1. What is the correct training for the maintenance and repair of gully cleansing and tanker equipment?

competencies.name: Operative uses secure access equipment when access the top of the vehicle
competencies.supportingText:
Operative only carries out any maintenance or repairs that they have been authorised to perform
  1. What is the company procedure for authorising maintenance and repair of gully cleansing and tanker equipment?

competencies.name: Operative returns to depot or workshop if secure access equipment is not available
Operative only carries out any maintenance or repairs that they have been trained  to perform
competencies.supportingText:
Operative does nothing to endanger the public while operating the vehicle and related equipment
  1. What is the company procedure for ensuring that the public and other road users are not endangered when carrying out gully cleansing and tanker operations?

competencies.name: Operative only carries out any maintenance or repairs that they have been authorised to perform
Operative does not ride on the back of work vehicle at any time
Operative does not  endanger the public while operating the vehicle and related equipment
Operative ensures that the directional arrow at the rear of the vehicle is properly displayed when not moving
Operative ensures that the flashing beacons are switched on when working
Operative ensures that the parking brake is applied when working
competencies.supportingText:
Operative avoids any conflict or argument with the general public and withdraws politely from a difficult situation and informs supervisor immediately
  1. What is the company procedure for handling any potential conflict with the public when carrying out gully cleansing and tanker operations?

competencies.name: Operative protects public from open coverings with open drops by using hazard warning signs, barriers or cones
Operative ensures pipe joints are watertight to avoid exposing anyone to contaminated water or causing pollution to the environment
Operative avoids any conflict or argument with the general public and withdraws politely from a difficult situation and informs supervisor immediately
Operative routes hoses to cause the least hazard to others
Operative uses ramps and warning signs when pipes cross any public road or walkway
Operative frequently checks  pressure gauges during operations
Operative ensures that the tank is at atmospheric pressure before unlatching doors and manhole clamps
Operative ensures that heat, sparks and flames are  kept from the proximity of the  tank unless it has been confirmed as gas-free
competencies.supportingText:
Operative reports covers that cannot be removed and leaves them in place
  1. What is the company procedure for reporting covers that cannot be moved to your supervisor?

competencies.name: Operative does not enter the tank for any reason

sections.name: D - Gully Cleansing and Tanker Operations

competencies.name: Operative uses approved manual handling techniques when removing covers, including those that are stuck
Operative reports covers that cannot be removed and leaves them in place
Operative places cover(s) nearby avoiding creating a trip hazard for road users or pedestrians
Operative uses the digging tool to test the content of the gully before using the hose
Operative removes obstructions or silt manually from the gully chamber using only tools supplied by the company
Operative removes waste using only the tools supplied by the company
Operative ensures waste and detritus is not left where it can cause a hazard to others
Operative engages the suction only when the end of the hose is inside the chamber
Operative reports blockage to the driver or supervisor and does not attempt to clear blockages by climbing on the vehicle
Operative does not use personal music equipment at work
Operative ensures there is sufficient overhead clearance when tipping
Operative checks that there are no overhead power lines near or above the vehicle body
Operative does not allow anyone to stand under an un‑propped tank
Operative uses correctly fitted props provided by the manufacturer and follows the manufacturer’s guidelines
Operative cleans and inspects the door-sealing ring and the clamp before tightening
Driver does not drive with the tank body raised
Driver moves the vehicle forward in a slow and controlled manner without sudden braking or change of direction to allow full discharge of the load
Driver keeps all movement of the vehicle to a minimum and to the shortest distance required for lowering of the body
competencies.supportingText:
Driver contacts supervisor if entry to the body of the tanker is necessary
  1. What is the company procedure for contacting your supervisor if you have to enter the body of the tanker?

competencies.name: Driver ensures that all doors and clamps are secured and the PTO (power take off) disengaged before driving off
competencies.supportingText:
Driver assesses the risk of entry to the body of the tanker following company procedures
  1. What is the company procedures for assessing risks involved in entering the body of the tanker?

competencies.name: Driver never enters the body of a gully sucker, septic tank or drainage system
competencies.supportingText:
